text: The Wright Renown is a single-decker body of a bus. It has a low floor. It was made from 1997 to 2002 by Wrightbus. The Wright Renown body was built on the Volvo B10BLE chassis. == Operators == In 1997, FirstGroup ordered 112 Wright Renowns for services in Manchester, Bristol, West Yorkshire and Northampton. From 1997 to 2001, FirstGroup ordered more Wright Renowns for services in South Yorkshire, Hampshire, Glasgow, Eastern Scotland and Aberdeen. From 1997 to 2001, Blazefield Group ordered 125 Wright Renowns for its Harrogate, Keighley, Yorkshire Coastliner, Lancashire United and Burnley bus companies. From 2001 to 2002, Blazefield Group ordered another 41 Wright Renowns, These were the last buses built on the Volvo B10BLE chassis for the UK market. From 1999 to 2000, Translink of Northern Ireland ordered 90 Wright Renowns, 45 were sent to Citybus of Belfast and 45 were sent to Ulsterbus. From 1999 to 2000 The Oxford Bus Company ordered Wright Renowns, these were made as dual-door buses (with doors in the middle) to deal with overcrowding in the tourist city. In 1999, Arriva ordered 30 Wright Renowns for its Northumbria, West Scotland and The Shires bus companies. From 1997 to 1999, Travel Dundee ordered 25 Wright Renowns. In 1997, Mainline Buses ordered 10 Wright Renowns, In 1998, First bought Mainline Buses and rebranded the company as First South Yorkshire. In 1998, First South Yorkshire ordered 20 Wright Renowns. From 1999 to 2000, CMT Buses ordered 18 Wright Renowns. Hutchinson's of Overtown and White of Walls, Shetland ordered Wright Renowns. ==References== ==Other websites== Category:Low-floor buses Renown
